Award.AwardTitle: Conference Travel Grant: Connecting Practioners and Scholars in Public Participation in STEM Research and in Community-Based Environmental Science to Enhance Informal STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. This travel grant focuses on broadening participation in STEM learning and advancing scholarship and practice related to Public Participation in STEM Research (PPSR). In PPSR, members of the public participate voluntarily in scientific processes, addressing real-world problems in ways that may include formulating research questions, conducting scientific experiments, collecting and analyzing data, interpreting results, making new discoveries, developing technologies and applications, and solving complex problems. Currently, participation in many PPSR projects does not often reflect the full range diversity in the nation. The Citizen Science Association (CSA), an organization that seeks to support the rigorous and ethical practice of citizen science--a form of PPSR--across a broad range of issues and communities, brings together PPSR practioners and scholars biennially. The CSA conference, to be held March 13-17, 2019, in Raleigh, North Carolina, will build networks and capacities to support scholarship and practice across the full range of citizen science and across diverse populations.

This travel grant supports 75 participants, 25 local and 50 national, from groups underrepresented in STEM, who are actively engaged in community-based environmental science and have not previously attended a CSA conference. Community-based environmental science projects, which often occur in minority communities, are increasingly relying on PPSR approaches, including engaging public participants in STEM learning through technology and the development of data literacies. Through this travel grant, the 2019 CSA conference will bring together the expertise and experiences of practioners and scholars from citizen science and community-based environmental science projects. The conference will facilitate four days of interactions and mutual learning with significant time for iterative reflection and active discussion to make the sessions personally relevant and meaningful. This intentionally allows for identifying areas of both commonalities and tensions across citizen science and community-based environmental science projects, with time to work through various approaches and issues with colleagues for greater learning. The interactions should allow for meaningful discussion of goals, theory, methods, recruitment and retention and other aspects of projects that make a difference in the success of projects. The structure of the conference includes panels, presentations, poster sessions, and discussion to increase the quality and extent of PPSR and community-based environmental science practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Citizen Science Association hosted its second biennial conference, CitSci2019, in Raleigh, NC on March 13-17, 2019. Through an award to the NC Museum of Natural Sciences (PI Cooper, Co-PI Wilson), the National Science Foundation supported community-based environmental science practitioners from underrepresented groups to attend and participate in the Conference.

Citizen science refers to many ways that non-scientists authentically work with scientists, which results in new discoveries as well as greater public literacy in STEM. The Citizen Science Association (CSA) is a professional membership-based organization supporting scientists in the rigorous and ethical practice of citizen science which enhances STEM learning for all populations. Prior to the Conference, the CSA membership had low racial diversity and minimal representation from small community-based organizations carrying out citizen science with groups underserved and underrepresented in STEM. This Conference award, funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, brought racial, ethnic, and community-based diversity to the CSA conference, membership, and leadership, for mutual benefits and the shared goal of increasing informal STEM learning and increasing community capacity for citizen science. This Conference award advanced networking and professional development around varied and innovative approaches to the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments, with an emphasis on technology and data literacy, and in all types of citizen science.

The Conference project met its goal to broaden the networks, membership, and leadership of the CSA to be inclusive of experts who work with low-income and minority community-based environmental science projects. The grant supported a scholarship program that brought in, to varied parts of the event, a critical mass of community-based environmental science practitioners who have not previously taken part in the Citizen Science Association (CSA) or its conference.

We received 99 applications and awarded 56 conference scholarships to individuals who were community-based environmental science practitioner and persons of color in the United States. All of the awardees were from marginalized groups: 38 Black or African American, 11 Hispanic/Latino; 5 Asian, and 2 Native American.  Of these, two were college students and two were teen youth leaders accompanied by adult colleagues. Geographic coverage included awardees flying in from many airports, including San Francisco, Phoenix, San Juan (Puerto Rico), LaGuardia, Miami, Pensacola, Newark, Detroit, JFK, O'Hare, Atlanta, Tuscon, LA, and Anchorage, with regional travelers from South Carolina and across North Carolina.

Scholarship recipients networked at the Opening Reception, attended and led workshops, symposia, and talks, participated in a Lunch 'n Learn session about low-cost sensor technology, and participated in a Working Group Roundtable event. Some highlights of the CSA Conference programming included multiple sessions related to the intersection of citizen science with inclusion efforts, research ethics, community-driven practices and principles, regulatory compliance and enforcement, public health, and more. Thus, the grant facilitated four days of causal and formal interactions between potential and current members and leaders of the CSA to co-negotiate building the CSA's organizational capacity to support a wider array of practitioners and scholars in broadening and increasing public engagement in citizen science and STEM learning.

Scholarship recipients joined several CSA working groups and created a new working group. The grant provided the first steps for broader engagement in the CSA and subsequent broadening of participation of marginalized groups, people of color, economically disadvantaged, and tribal populations in STEM learning via citizen science.
